chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: The OSATE Graphical Editor allows viewing and manipulating AADL declarative models in a graphical way.

section.title: Creating a new AADL Package
section.para: A new AADL package and an associated diagram can be created by using a wizard.

listitem.para: Open the new file dialog by selecting File->New->Other...
Select Aadl Package (Graphical).
Enter a name for the new package.
Select the AADL Project to create the package inside.
Select Finish.

section.para: The new package will appear in the graphical editor.

section.title: Opening an Existing AADL Model
section.para: An existing AADL model can be opened in the graphical editor. Changes made to either the AADL source or the diagram will be reflected in the other.

listitem.para: Open an existing AADL source file.
Right click the AADL package or component in the Outline view.

Select Open Package Diagram to open the package diagram for the package that contains the element. Select Open Classifier Diagram to open the diagram for the selected classifier. The diagram will be created if one does not already exist. The appropriate diagram will appear in the graphical editor.

chapter.title: Navigating Between Diagrams
chapter.para: The graphical editor supports navigating between related diagrams in several ways.

section.title: Opening an Associated Diagram
section.para: Diagrams associated with a particular element can be opened by double-clicking on the model element. For example, double-clicking a classifier inside a package diagram will open that classifier's diagram. Alternatively, the associated diagram can be open by right-clicking on the element and selecting Open Associated Diagram from the context menu.

section.title: Opening an Element's Package Diagram
section.para: When viewing a diagram, the package diagram associated with an element can be opened by right-clicking inside the diagram or element and selecting Go to Package Diagram from the context menu.

section.title: Opening the Type Diagram for a Component Implementation
section.para: When viewing a component implementation diagram, the diagram for the component implementation's type can be opened by right-clicking inside the diagram and selecting Go to Type Diagram from the context menu.

chapter.title: Editing AADL Models
chapter.para: The graphical editor allows editing AADL models graphically. As changes are made to the diagram, the AADL model is updated automatically. Additionally, as the textual AADL model is editing using OSATE, the diagram is updated to reflect changes.

section.title: Basics
section.para: Many of the operations in the graphical editor apply to multiple types of elements.

section.title: Deleting
section.para: An element can be deleted from the AADL model by selecting it and pressing the delete key. An element can also be deleted by right-clicking on it and selecting Delete from the context menu.
Elements can only be deleted when viewing the element which contains it. For example, a feature defined in a system type cannot be deleted while editing the diagram of a system implementation.

section.title: Renaming
section.para: An element can be renamed using the graphical editor.

listitem.para: Select the item to be renamed.
Click the name label. An editable field will appear.
Adjust the name as desired.
Press the Enter key.

section.para: Elements can only be renamed when viewing the element which contains it. For example, a feature defined in a system type cannot be renamed while editing the diagram of a system implementation.

section.title: Refining
section.para: Appropriate elements can be refined by right-clicking on them and selecting Refine from the context menu. Once an element is refined. Deleting a refined element will only delete the refinement.

section.title: Editing Property Associations
section.para: Property associations can be edited using OSATE's AADL Property Values view. Selecting an element in the diagram updates the view to show property values for that element.

section.title: Performing Diagram Layout
section.para: When creating a new diagram from an AADL model, the editor lays out the diagram automatically. The layout of the diagram can be redone by right clicking inside the diagram and select Layout Diagram. Doing so will adjust the positions of all the shapes in the diagram.

section.title: Classifiers
section.para: The graphical editor allows editing AADL classifiers such as component types, component implementations, and feature groups.

section.title: Creating
section.para: When viewing a package diagram, classifiers can be created by using the palette.

listitem.para: Open a package diagram.
Drag the appropriate classifier type from the palette onto the diagram.
If a component implementation was dropped onto the diagram, select the classifier for the implementation to implement or extend.

section.title: Extending
section.para: The editor allows classifier extensions to be specified in the package view. That is, the editor allows the specification of type extensions and implementation relationships.

section.title: Using the Palette to Extend a Classifier

listitem.para: While editing a package diagram, select Extension from the Palette.
Click on the classifier which will be the extension.
Click the classifier that is being extended. An arrow will now appear. The type of arrow is determined whether the extension is an implementation or type extension.

section.title: Using the Context Menu to Set Extended Classifier
section.para: Specifying an extension using the context menu allows extending classifiers in other packages.

listitem.para: Right-click on the classifier which will be the extension and select Set Extended Classifier... from the context menu.
Select the classifier to extend.
Select OK. The appropriate arrow indicating the extension will appear.

section.title: Features
section.para: The editor allows editing AADL features. Features may be displayed on the left or the right of their container.

section.title: Creating
section.para: Features can be created by using the palette.

section.title: Setting the Feature Classifier
section.para: The classifier can be set on features such as feature groups, data ports, and access features. Set the classifier by right clicking on the feature and selecting Set Classifier... from the context menu.

section.title: Setting the Feature Direction (Directional Features Only)
section.para: To set the direction of a directional feature, right-click on the feature and select Set Direction to In, Set Direction to Out, or Set Direction to In and Out from the context menu.

section.title: Setting Access Kind (Access Features Only)
section.para: To set the direction of an access feature, right-click on the feature and select Set Kind to Provides or Set Kind to Requires from the context menu.

section.title: Subcomponents
section.para: The graphical editor allows editing subcomponents when viewing a component implementation diagram.

section.title: Creating
section.para: When viewing a component implementation diagram, a subcomponent can be creating by using the palette. Drag the appropriate subcomponent type from the palette to the desired location. A new subcomponent will appear.

section.title: Setting the Classifier
section.para: Select the subcomponent classifier by right-clicking on the subcomponent and selecting Set Classifier... from the context menu. After selecting the classifier, the subcomponent will be updated to show the appropriate features.

section.title: Setting Modes
section.para: To set the modes in which subcomponents are active, see .

section.title: Flows
section.para: The graphical editor support creating and editing flow specifications, flow implementations, and end-to-end flows.

section.title: Creating Flow Sources
section.para: Flow sources can be created when editing a component type. Create the flow source by right-clicking on an appropriate feature and selecting Create Source from the context menu. The new flow source will appear.

section.title: Creating Flow Sinks
section.para: Flow sources can be created when editing a component type. Create the flow source by right-clicking on an appropriate feature and selecting Create Sink from the context menu. The new flow sink will appear.

section.title: Creating Flow Paths
section.para: When editing a component type, flow paths can be created using the palette.

listitem.para: Select Flow Path from the palette.
Click the feature to use as the start of the flow path.
Click the feature to use as the end of the path. The new flow path will appear.

section.title: Editing Flow Implementations and End-to-End Flows
section.para: When editing a component implementation, flow implementations and end-to-end flow can be edited using the flow editor. It can be accessed by right-clicking in the diagram and selecting Edit Flows... from the context menu.

section.title: Highlighting Flow Implementations and End-to-End Flows
section.para: Selecting a flow implementation or end-to-end flow from the flow drop-down in the toolbar will highlight the flow.

section.title: Modes
section.para: The graphical editor allows editing the modes and mode transitions defined in the AADL model.

section.title: Creating Modes
section.para: When editing a component type, modes can be created by selecting Mode from the palette.

section.title: Setting the Initial Mode
section.para: A mode can be designated as the initial mode by right-clicking on it and selecting Change to Initial Mode from the context menu.

section.title: Creating Mode Transitions
section.para: Mode transitions can be created using the palette.

listitem.para: Select Mode Transition from the palette.
Click the starting mode.
Click the destination mode. The Select Trigger Ports dialog will appear.
Select the ports to use as the triggers for the transition. Multiple ports can be selected by holding down Ctrl.
Select OK. The new mode transition will appear.

section.title: Setting Mode Transition Triggers
section.para: A mode transition's trigger ports can be modified by right-clicking on the mode transition and selecting Set Mode Transition Triggers... from the context menu.

section.title: Switching Between Derived and Non-derived Modes
section.para: The editor allows specifying whether modes declared inside the component type are derived from its containing component. The usage of derived modes corresponds to a component type with a requires modes declaration while non-derived modes correspond to a component type with a modes declaration.

The component type can be swapped between using derived and non-derived modes by right-clicking inside the component type and selecting Change to Derived Modes or Change to Non-derived Modes from the context menu.

section.title: Highlighting
section.para: Selecting a mode from the mode drop-down in the toolbar will highlight elements applicable to the mode.

section.title: Selecting Active Components
section.para: The editor allows specifying the modes in which a modal element, such as a subcomponent, is active as well as the mapping between modes in the case of derived modes. The modes can be specified by right-clicking on the element and selecting Configure In Modes... from the context menu.

chapter.title: Troubleshooting
chapter.para: The following section contains solutions to known issues as well as instructions for reporting problems with the graphical editor.

section.title: Build Automatically
section.para: Project->Build Automatically must be enabled. If it is not enabled, the graphical editor will not function properly.

section.title: Updating a Diagram
section.para: In most cases the graphical editor will automatically update diagrams to reflect changes to the AADL Model. If a diagram has not been updated for any reason, it can be updated manually by right-clicking inside the diagram and selecting Update from the context menu.

section.title: Reporting Bugs
section.para: Bugs should be reported to the issue tracker on the graphical editor's GitHub Site.
